slides.title: Font Fundamentals
slides.content:
# CSS Fonts üÖ∞Ô∏è

Choosing the right font is key to readability and design.

## Font Family
The `font-family` property specifies the font for an element.

It should hold several font names as a "fallback" system. If the browser does not support the first font, it tries the next font.

```css
p {
  font-family: "Times New Roman", Times, serif;
}
```
Start with the specific font, then a generic family (`serif`, `sans-serif`, `monospace`).

slides.title: Serif vs Sans-Serif
slides.content:
# Serif vs Sans-Serif ‚úíÔ∏è

## Serif
Have small lines (serifs) at the ends of characters. Considered formal and elegant.
- *Example:* Times New Roman, Georgia.

## Sans-Serif
"Sans" means without. These fonts do not have small lines. Considered modern and clean.
- *Example:* Arial, Helvetica, Roboto.

> üì± **Design Tip:** Sans-serif fonts are generally easier to read on screens.

slides.title: Google Fonts
slides.content:
# Web Fonts (Google Fonts) üåê

To use a font that isn't standard on all computers, use Google Fonts.

1. Link the font in `<head>`.
2. Use it in CSS.

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Sofia">
<style>
body {
  font-family: "Sofia", sans-serif;
}
</style>
```

slides.title: Text Alignment
slides.content:
# Text Alignment üìê

`text-align` is used to set the horizontal alignment of text.

- `left` (default)
- `right`
- `center`
- `justify` (stretches text to fill width)

```css
h1 {
  text-align: center;
}
```

## Vertical Alignment
`vertical-align` sets vertical alignment of an inline element (like an image next to text).

slides.title: Text Decoration
slides.content:
# Text Decoration ‚ú®

Primarily used to remove underlines from links.

```css
a {
  text-decoration: none;
}
```

Other values:
- `underline`
- `overline`
- `line-through` (strikethrough)

slides.title: Font Size and Weight
slides.content:
# Size and Weight üìè

## Font Size
`font-size` sets the size. Can use `px`, `em`, `rem`, or `%`.

```css
h1 { font-size: 40px; }
p { font-size: 1.25rem; } /* relative to root html size */
```

## Font Weight
`font-weight` sets the thickness.
- `normal` (400)
- `bold` (700)

```css
p.thicker { font-weight: 900; }
```

slides.title: Spacing
slides.content:
# Text Spacing ‚ÜîÔ∏è

## Letter Spacing
Space between characters.
```css
h1 { letter-spacing: 3px; }
```

## Line Height
Space between lines of text (Leading).
```css
p { line-height: 1.6; }
```
A unitless number is preferred (e.g., 1.5 times the font size).

## Word Spacing
Space between words.
```css
p { word-spacing: 10px; }
```

slides.title: Text Shadow
Summary
slides.content:
# Summary üÖ∞Ô∏è

Typography defines the reading experience.

## Key Takeaways

- ‚úÖ **font-family:** Defines the font stack (fallback system).
- ‚úÖ **Web Fonts:** Use Google Fonts for custom typography.
- ‚úÖ **text-align:** Controls left/center/right alignment.
- ‚úÖ **line-height:** Improves readability of paragraphs.
- ‚úÖ **font-size/weight:** Controls scale and emphasis.
